member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy
member.summary: Implements the curl_easy_xxx API.
member.remarks: This is the most important class in libcurl.NET. It wraps a CURL* handle and provides delegates through which callbacks (such as CURLOPT_WRITEFUNCTION and CURLOPT_READFUNCTION) are implemented.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.WriteFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL has data for the client.
member.remarks:
For usage, see the example EasyGet.cs. Arguments passed to the delegate implementation include:
Argument Description
buf Data cURL is providing to the client.
size Size of a character, usually 1.
nmemb Number of characters.
extraData Client-provided extra data.
Your implementation should return the number of bytes (not characters) processed. Return 0 to abort the transfer.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.ReadFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL wants to read data from the client.
member.remarks:
For usage, see the sample Upload.cs. Arguments passed to the recipient include:
Argument Description
buf Buffer into which your client should write data for cURL.
size Size of a character, usually 1.
nmemb Number of characters.
extraData Client-provided extra data.
Your implementation should return the number of bytes (not characters) written to buf. Return 0 to abort the transfer.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.ProgressFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL wants to report progress.
member.remarks:
For usage, see the sample Upload.cs. Arguments passed to the recipient include:
Argument Description
extraData Client-provided extra data.
dlTotal Number of bytes to download.
dlNow Number of bytes downloaded so far.
ulTotal Number of bytes to upload.
ulNow Number of bytes uploaded so far.
Your implementation should return 0 to continue, or a non-zero value to abort the transfer.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.DebugFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL has debug information for the client.
member.remarks:
For usage, see the sample Upload.cs. Arguments passed to the recipient include:
Argument Description
infoType Type of debug information, see .
message Debug information as a string.
extraData Client-provided extra data.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.HeaderFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL has header data for the client.
member.remarks:
For usage, see the sample Headers.cs. Arguments passed to the recipient include:
Argument Description
buf Header data from cURL to the client.
size Size of a character, in bytes.
nmemb Number of characters.
extraData Client-provided extra data.
Your implementation should return the number of bytes (not characters) processed. Usually this is size * nmemb. Return -1 to abort the transfer.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.SSLContextFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL wants to report an SSL event.
member.remarks:
For usage, see the sample SSLGet.cs. Arguments passed to the recipient include:
Argument Description
ctx
An object that wraps an OpenSSL SSL_CTX pointer.
extraData Client-provided extra data.
Your implementation should return a , which should be if everything is okay.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Easy.IoctlFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL needs for the client to perform an IOCTL operation. An example might be when an FTP upload requires rewinding of the input file to deal with a resend occasioned by an error.
member.remarks:
Argument Description
cmd
A ; for now, only CURLIOCMD_RESTARTREAD should be passed.
extraData Client-provided extra data; in the case of an FTP upload, it might be a FileStream object.
Your implementation should return a , which should be if everything is okay.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOERR
member.summary: Your handler for the delegate should return a member of this enumeration.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOERR.CURLIOE_OK
member.summary: Indicate that the callback processed everything okay.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOERR.CURLIOE_UNKNOWNCMD
member.summary: Unknown command sent to callback. Right now, only CURLIOCMD_RESTARTREAD is supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOERR.CURLIOE_FAILRESTART
member.summary: Indicate to libcurl that a restart failed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOERR.CURLIOE_LAST
member.summary: End of enumeration marker, don't use in a client application.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOCMD
member.summary: Your handler for the delegate is passed one of these values as its first parameter. Right now, the only supported value is CURLIOCMD_RESTARTREAD.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOCMD.CURLIOCMD_NOP
member.summary: No IOCTL operation; we should never see this.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOCMD.CURLIOCMD_RESTARTREAD
member.summary: When this is sent, your callback may need to, for example, rewind a local file that is being sent via FTP.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLIOCMD.CURLIOCMD_LAST
member.summary: End of enumeration marker, don't use in a client application.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE
member.summary: A member of this enumeration is passed as the first parameter to the delegate to which libcurl passes debug messages.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_TEXT
member.summary: The data is informational text.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_HEADER_IN
member.summary: The data is header (or header-like) data received from the peer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_HEADER_OUT
member.summary: The data is header (or header-like) data sent to the peer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_DATA_IN
member.summary: The data is protocol data received from the peer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_DATA_OUT
member.summary: The data is protocol data sent to the peer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_SSL_DATA_IN
member.summary: The data is SSL-related data sent to the peer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_SSL_DATA_OUT
member.summary: The data is SSL-related data received from the peer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFOTYPE.CURLINFO_END
member.summary: End of enumeration marker, don't use in a client application.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode
member.summary: Status code returned from functions.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_OK
member.summary: All fine. Proceed as usual.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_ABORTED_BY_CALLBACK
member.summary: Aborted by callback. An internal callback returned "abort" to libcurl.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_BAD_CALLING_ORDER
member.summary: Internal error. A function was called in a bad order.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_BAD_CONTENT_ENCODING
member.summary: Unrecognized transfer encoding.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_BAD_DOWNLOAD_RESUME
member.summary: Attempting FTP resume beyond file size.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_BAD_FUNCTION_ARGUMENT
member.summary: Internal error. A function was called with a bad parameter.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_BAD_PASSWORD_ENTERED
member.summary: Bad password entered. An error was signaled when the password was entered. This can also be the result of a "bad password" returned from a specified password callback.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_COULDNT_CONNECT
member.summary: Failed to connect to host or proxy.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_COULDNT_RESOLVE_HOST
member.summary: Couldn't resolve host. The given remote host was not resolved.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_COULDNT_RESOLVE_PROXY
member.summary: Couldn't resolve proxy. The given proxy host could not be resolved.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FAILED_INIT
member.summary: Very early initialization code failed. This is likely to be an internal error or problem.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FILESIZE_EXCEEDED
member.summary: Maximum file size exceeded.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FILE_COULDNT_READ_FILE
member.summary: A file given with FILE:// couldn't be opened. Most likely because the file path doesn't identify an existing file. Did you check file permissions?

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_ACCESS_DENIED
member.summary: We were denied access when trying to login to an FTP server or when trying to change working directory to the one given in the URL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_CANT_GET_HOST
member.summary: An internal failure to lookup the host used for the new connection.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_CANT_RECONNECT
member.summary: A bad return code on either PASV or EPSV was sent by the FTP server, preventing libcurl from being able to continue.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_COULDNT_GET_SIZE
member.summary: The FTP SIZE command returned error. SIZE is not a kosher FTP command, it is an extension and not all servers support it. This is not a surprising error.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_COULDNT_RETR_FILE
member.summary: This was either a weird reply to a 'RETR' command or a zero byte transfer complete.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_COULDNT_SET_ASCII
member.summary: libcurl failed to set ASCII transfer type (TYPE A).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_COULDNT_SET_BINARY
member.summary: Received an error when trying to set the transfer mode to binary.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_COULDNT_STOR_FILE
member.summary: FTP couldn't STOR file. The server denied the STOR operation. The error buffer usually contains the server's explanation to this.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_COULDNT_USE_REST
member.summary: The FTP REST command returned error. This should never happen if the server is sane.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_PORT_FAILED
member.summary: The FTP PORT command returned error. This mostly happen when you haven't specified a good enough address for libcurl to use. See .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_QUOTE_ERROR
member.summary: When sending custom "QUOTE" commands to the remote server, one of the commands returned an error code that was 400 or higher.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_SSL_FAILED
member.summary: Requested FTP SSL level failed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_USER_PASSWORD_INCORRECT
member.summary: The FTP server rejected access to the server after the password was sent to it. It might be because the username and/or the password were incorrect or just that the server is not allowing you access for the moment etc.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_WEIRD_227_FORMAT
member.summary: FTP servers return a 227-line as a response to a PASV command. If libcurl fails to parse that line, this return code is passed back.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_WEIRD_PASS_REPLY
member.summary: After having sent the FTP password to the server, libcurl expects a proper reply. This error code indicates that an unexpected code was returned.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_WEIRD_PASV_REPLY
member.summary: libcurl failed to get a sensible result back from the server as a response to either a PASV or a EPSV command. The server is flawed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_WEIRD_SERVER_REPLY
member.summary: After connecting to an FTP server, libcurl expects to get a certain reply back. This error code implies that it got a strange or bad reply. The given remote server is probably not an OK FTP server.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_WEIRD_USER_REPLY
member.summary: After having sent user name to the FTP server, libcurl expects a proper reply. This error code indicates that an unexpected code was returned.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FTP_WRITE_ERROR
member.summary: After a completed file transfer, the FTP server did not respond a proper "transfer successful" code.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_FUNCTION_NOT_FOUND
member.summary: Function not found. A required LDAP function was not found.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_GOT_NOTHING
member.summary: Nothing was returned from the server, and under the circumstances, getting nothing is considered an error.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_HTTP_POST_ERROR
member.summary: This is an odd error that mainly occurs due to internal confusion.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_HTTP_RANGE_ERROR
member.summary: The HTTP server does not support or accept range requests.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_HTTP_RETURNED_ERROR
member.summary: This is returned if is set TRUE and the HTTP server returns an error code that is >= 400.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_INTERFACE_FAILED
member.summary: Interface error. A specified outgoing interface could not be used. Set which interface to use for outgoing connections' source IP address with .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_LAST
member.summary: End-of-enumeration marker; do not use in client applications.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_LDAP_CANNOT_BIND
member.summary: LDAP cannot bind. LDAP bind operation failed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_LDAP_INVALID_URL
member.summary: Invalid LDAP URL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_LDAP_SEARCH_FAILED
member.summary: LDAP search failed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_LIBRARY_NOT_FOUND
member.summary: Library not found. The LDAP library was not found.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_MALFORMAT_USER
member.summary: Malformat user. User name badly specified. *Not currently used*

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_OBSOLETE
member.summary: This is not an error. This used to be another error code in an old libcurl version and is currently unused.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_OPERATION_TIMEOUTED
member.summary: Operation timeout. The specified time-out period was reached according to the conditions.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_OUT_OF_MEMORY
member.summary: Out of memory. A memory allocation request failed. This is serious badness and things are severely messed up if this ever occurs.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_PARTIAL_FILE
member.summary: A file transfer was shorter or larger than expected. This happens when the server first reports an expected transfer size, and then delivers data that doesn't match the previously given size.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_READ_ERROR
member.summary: There was a problem reading a local file or an error returned by the read callback.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_RECV_ERROR
member.summary: Failure with receiving network data.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SEND_ERROR
member.summary: Failed sending network data.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURL_SEND_FAIL_REWIND
member.summary: Sending the data requires a rewind that failed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SHARE_IN_USE
member.summary: Share is in use.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_CACERT
member.summary: Problem with the CA cert (path? access rights?)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_CERTPROBLEM
member.summary: There's a problem with the local client certificate.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_CIPHER
member.summary: Couldn't use specified cipher.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_CONNECT_ERROR
member.summary: A problem occurred somewhere in the SSL/TLS handshake. You really want to use the delegate and read the message there as it pinpoints the problem slightly more. It could be certificates (file formats, paths, permissions), passwords, and others.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_ENGINE_INITFAILED
member.summary: Failed to initialize SSL engine.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_ENGINE_NOTFOUND
member.summary: The specified crypto engine wasn't found.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_ENGINE_SETFAILED
member.summary: Failed setting the selected SSL crypto engine as default!

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_SSL_PEER_CERTIFICATE
member.summary: The remote server's SSL certificate was deemed not OK.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_TELNET_OPTION_SYNTAX
member.summary: A telnet option string was improperly formatted.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS
member.summary: Too many redirects. When following redirects, libcurl hit the maximum amount. Set your limit with .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_UNKNOWN_TELNET_OPTION
member.summary: An option set with was not recognized/known. Refer to the appropriate documentation.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_UNSUPPORTED_PROTOCOL
member.summary: The URL you passed to libcurl used a protocol that this libcurl does not support. The support might be a compile-time option that wasn't used, it can be a misspelled protocol string or just a protocol libcurl has no code for.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_URL_MALFORMAT
member.summary: The URL was not properly formatted.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_URL_MALFORMAT_USER
member.summary: URL user malformatted. The user-part of the URL syntax was not correct.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLcode.CURLE_WRITE_ERROR
member.summary: An error occurred when writing received data to a local file, or an error was returned to libcurl from a write callback.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLproxyType
member.summary: This enumeration contains values used to specify the proxy type when using the option when calling

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLproxyType.CURLPROXY_HTTP
member.summary: Ordinary HTTP proxy.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLproxyType.CURLPROXY_SOCKS4
member.summary: Use if the proxy supports SOCKS4 user authentication. If you're unfamiliar with this, consult your network administrator.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLproxyType.CURLPROXY_SOCKS5
member.summary: Use if the proxy supports SOCKS5 user authentication. If you're unfamiliar with this, consult your network administrator.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth
member.summary: This enumeration contains values used to specify the HTTP authentication when using the option when calling

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_NONE
member.summary: No authentication.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_BASIC
member.summary: HTTP Basic authentication. This is the default choice, and the only method that is in wide-spread use and supported virtually everywhere. This is sending the user name and password over the network in plain text, easily captured by others.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_DIGEST
member.summary: HTTP Digest authentication. Digest authentication is defined in RFC2617 and is a more secure way to do authentication over public networks than the regular old-fashioned Basic method.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_GSSNEGOTIATE
member.summary:
HTTP GSS-Negotiate authentication. The GSS-Negotiate (also known as plain "Negotiate") method was designed by Microsoft and is used in their web applications. It is primarily meant as a support for Kerberos5 authentication but may be also used along with another authentication methods. For more information see IETF draft draft-brezak-spnego-http-04.txt.
You need to use a version of libcurl.NET built with a suitable GSS-API library for this to work. This is not currently standard.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_NTLM
member.summary: HTTP NTLM authentication. A proprietary protocol invented and used by Microsoft. It uses a challenge-response and hash concept similar to Digest, to prevent the password from being eavesdropped.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_ANY
member.summary: This is a convenience macro that sets all bits and thus makes libcurl pick any it finds suitable. libcurl will automatically select the one it finds most secure.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpAuth.CURLAUTH_ANYSAFE
member.summary: This is a convenience macro that sets all bits except Basic and thus makes libcurl pick any it finds suitable. libcurl will automatically select the one it finds most secure.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpSSL
member.summary: This enumeration contains values used to specify the FTP SSL level using the option when calling

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpSSL.CURLFTPSSL_NONE
member.summary: Don't attempt to use SSL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpSSL.CURLFTPSSL_TRY
member.summary: Try using SSL, proceed as normal otherwise.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpSSL.CURLFTPSSL_CONTROL
member.summary: Require SSL for the control connection or fail with .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpSSL.CURLFTPSSL_ALL
member.summary: Require SSL for all communication or fail with .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpSSL.CURLFTPSSL_LAST
member.summary: End-of-enumeration marker. Do not use in a client application.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpAuth
member.summary: This enumeration contains values used to specify the FTP SSL authorization level using the option when calling

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpAuth.CURLFTPAUTH_DEFAULT
member.summary: Let libcurl decide on the authorization scheme.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpAuth.CURLFTPAUTH_SSL
member.summary: Use "AUTH SSL".

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpAuth.CURLFTPAUTH_TLS
member.summary: Use "AUTH TLS".

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLftpAuth.CURLFTPAUTH_LAST
member.summary: End-of-enumeration marker. Do not use in a client application.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption
member.summary: One of these is passed as the first parameter to . The Description column of the table describes the value that should be passed as the second parameter.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_AUTOREFERER
member.summary: Pass a true parameter to enable this. When enabled, libcurl will automatically set the Referer: field in requests where it follows a Location: redirect.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_BUFFERSIZE
member.summary: Pass an int specifying your preferred size for the receive buffer in libcurl. The main point of this would be that the write callback gets called more often and with smaller chunks. This is just treated as a request, not an order. You cannot be guaranteed to actually get the requested size. (Added in 7.10)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_CAINFO
member.summary: Pass a string naming a file holding one or more certificates to verify the peer with. This only makes sense when used in combination with the CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER option.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_CAPATH
member.summary: Pass a string naming a directory holding multiple CA certificates to verify the peer with. The certificate directory must be prepared using the openssl c_rehash utility. This only makes sense when used in combination with the CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER option. The CURLOPT_CAPATH function apparently does not work in Windows due to some limitation in openssl. (Added in 7.9.8)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_CLOSEPOLICY
member.summary: Pass an int. This option sets what policy libcurl should use when the connection cache is filled and one of the open connections has to be closed to make room for a new connection. This must be one of the members. Use to make libcurl close the connection that was least recently used, that connection is also least likely to be capable of re-use. Use to make libcurl close the oldest connection, the one that was created first among the ones in the connection cache. The other close policies are not supported yet.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_CONNECTTIMEOUT
member.summary: Time-out connect operations after this amount of seconds, if connects are OK within this time, then fine... This only aborts the connect phase. [Only works on unix-style/SIGALRM operating systems]

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_COOKIE
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. It will be used to set a cookie in the http request. The format of the string should be NAME=CONTENTS, where NAME is the cookie name and CONTENTS is what the cookie should contain.
If you need to set multiple cookies, you need to set them all using a single option and thus you need to concatenate them all in one single string. Set multiple cookies in one string like this: "name1=content1; name2=content2;" etc.
Using this option multiple times will only make the latest string override the previously ones.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_COOKIEFILE
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. It should contain the name of your file holding cookie data to read. The cookie data may be in Netscape / Mozilla cookie data format or just regular HTTP-style headers dumped to a file.
Given an empty or non-existing file, this option will enable cookies for this Easy object, making it understand and parse received cookies and then use matching cookies in future request.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_COOKIEJAR
member.summary:
Pass a file name as string. This will make libcurl write all internally known cookies to the specified file when is called. If no cookies are known, no file will be created. Using this option also enables cookies for this session, so if you for example follow a location it will make matching cookies get sent accordingly.
If the cookie jar file can't be created or written to (when is called), libcurl will not and cannot report an error for this. Using CURLOPT_VERBOSE or CURLOPT_DEBUGFUNCTION will get a warning to display, but that is the only visible feedback you get about this possibly lethal situation.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_COOKIESESSION
member.summary: Pass a bool set to true to mark this as a new cookie "session". It will force libcurl to ignore all cookies it is about to load that are "session cookies" from the previous session. By default, libcurl always stores and loads all cookies, independent of whether they are session cookies. Session cookies are cookies without expiry date and they are meant to be alive and existing for this "session" only.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_CRLF
member.summary: Convert Unix newlines to CRLF newlines on transfers.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_CUSTOMREQUEST
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. It will be used instead of GET or HEAD when doing an HTTP request, or instead of LIST or NLST when doing an ftp directory listing. This is useful for doing DELETE or other more or less obscure HTTP requests. Don't do this at will, make sure your server supports the command first.
Restore to the internal default by setting this to null.
Many people have wrongly used this option to replace the entire request with their own, including multiple headers and POST contents. While that might work in many cases, it will cause libcurl to send invalid requests and it could possibly confuse the remote server badly. Use CURLOPT_POST and CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS to set POST data. Use CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER to replace or extend the set of headers sent by libcurl. Use CURLOPT_HTTP_VERSION to change HTTP version.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_DEBUGDATA
member.summary: Pass an object referene to whatever you want passed to your delegate's extraData argument. This reference is not used internally by libcurl, it is only passed to the delegate.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_DEBUGFUNCTION
member.summary: Pass a reference to an delegate. CURLOPT_VERBOSE must be in effect. This delegate receives debug information, as specified with the argument. This function must return 0.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_DNS_CACHE_TIMEOUT
member.summary: Pass an int, specifying the timeout in seconds. Name resolves will be kept in memory for this number of seconds. Set to zero (0) to completely disable caching, or set to -1 to make the cached entries remain forever. By default, libcurl caches this info for 60 seconds.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_DNS_USE_GLOBAL_CACHE
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_EDGSOCKET
member.summary: Pass a string containing the path name to the Entropy Gathering Daemon socket. It will be used to seed the random engine for SSL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_ENCODING
member.summary: Sets the contents of the Accept-Encoding: header sent in an HTTP request, and enables decoding of a response when a Content-Encoding: header is received. Three encodings are supported: identity, which does nothing, deflate which requests the server to compress its response using the zlib algorithm, and gzip which requests the gzip algorithm. If a zero-length string is set, then an Accept-Encoding: header containing all supported encodings is sent.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_ERRORBUFFER
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FAILONERROR
member.summary: A true parameter tells the library to fail silently if the HTTP code returned is equal to or larger than 300. The default action would be to return the page normally, ignoring that code.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FILETIME
member.summary: Pass a bool. If it is true, libcurl will attempt to get the modification date of the remote document in this operation. This requires that the remote server sends the time or replies to a time querying command. The function with the argument can be used after a transfer to extract the received time (if any).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FOLLOWLOCATION
member.summary:
A true parameter tells the library to follow any Location: header that the server sends as part of an HTTP header.
this means that the library will re-send the same request on the new location and follow new Location: headers all the way until no more such headers are returned. CURLOPT_MAXREDIRS can be used to limit the number of redirects libcurl will follow.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FORBID_REUSE
member.summary: Pass a bool. Set to true to make the next transfer explicitly close the connection when done. Normally, libcurl keeps all connections alive when done with one transfer in case there comes a succeeding one that can re-use them. This option should be used with caution and only if you understand what it does. Set to false to have libcurl keep the connection open for possibly later re-use (default behavior).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FRESH_CONNECT
member.summary: Pass a bool. Set to true to make the next transfer use a new (fresh) connection by force. If the connection cache is full before this connection, one of the existing connections will be closed as according to the selected or default policy. This option should be used with caution and only if you understand what it does. Set this to false to have libcurl attempt re-using an existing connection (default behavior).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTPACCOUNT
member.summary: String that will be passed to the FTP server when it requests account info.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTPAPPEND
member.summary: A true parameter tells the library to append to the remote file instead of overwrite it. This is only useful when uploading to an ftp site.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTPLISTONLY
member.summary:
A true parameter tells the library to just list the names of an ftp directory, instead of doing a full directory listing that would include file sizes, dates etc.
This causes an FTP NLST command to be sent. Beware that some FTP servers list only files in their response to NLST; they might not include subdirectories and symbolic links.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTPPORT
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. It will be used to get the IP address to use for the ftp PORT instruction. The PORT instruction tells the remote server to connect to our specified IP address. The string may be a plain IP address, a host name, an network interface name (under Unix) or just a '-' letter to let the library use your systems default IP address. Default FTP operations are passive, and thus won't use PORT.
You disable PORT again and go back to using the passive version by setting this option to NULL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTPSSLAUTH
member.summary:
When FTP over SSL/TLS is selected (with CURLOPT_FTP_SSL), this option can be used to change libcurl's default action which is to first try "AUTH SSL" and then "AUTH TLS" in this order, and proceed when a OK response has been received.
Pass a member of the enumeration.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTP_CREATE_MISSING_DIRS
member.summary: Pass a bool. If the value is true, cURL will attempt to create any remote directory that it fails to CWD into. CWD is the command that changes working directory. (Added in 7.10.7)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTP_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT
member.summary: Pass an int. Causes libcurl to set a timeout period (in seconds) on the amount of time that the server is allowed to take in order to generate a response message for a command before the session is considered hung. Note that while libcurl is waiting for a response, this value overrides CURLOPT_TIMEOUT. It is recommended that if used in conjunction with CURLOPT_TIMEOUT, you set CURLOPT_FTP_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT to a value smaller than CURLOPT_TIMEOUT. (Added in 7.10.8)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTP_SSL
member.summary: Pass a member of the enumeration.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTP_USE_EPRT
member.summary: Pass a bool. If the value is true, it tells curl to use the EPRT (and LPRT) command when doing active FTP downloads (which is enabled by CURLOPT_FTPPORT). Using EPRT means that it will first attempt to use EPRT and then LPRT before using PORT, but if you pass false to this option, it will not try using EPRT or LPRT, only plain PORT. (Added in 7.10.5)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_FTP_USE_EPSV
member.summary: Pass a bool. If the value is true, it tells curl to use the EPSV command when doing passive FTP downloads (which it always does by default). Using EPSV means that it will first attempt to use EPSV before using PASV, but if you pass false to this option, it will not try using EPSV, only plain PASV.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HEADER
member.summary: A true parameter tells the library to include the header in the body output. This is only relevant for protocols that actually have headers preceding the data (like HTTP).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HEADERDATA
member.summary: Object reference to pass to the delegate. Note that if you specify the CURLOPT_HEADERFUNCTION, this is the reference you'll get as the extraData parameter.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HEADERFUNCTION
member.summary: Provide an delegate reference. This delegate gets called by libcurl as soon as there is received header data that needs to be written down. The headers are guaranteed to be written one-by-one and only complete lines are written. Parsing headers should be easy enough using this. The size of the data contained in buf is size multiplied with nmemb. Return the number of bytes actually written or return -1 to signal error to the library (it will cause it to abort the transfer with a return code).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTP200ALIASES
member.summary:
Pass an of aliases to be treated as valid HTTP 200 responses. Some servers respond with a custom header response line. For example, IceCast servers respond with "ICY 200 OK". By including this string in your list of aliases, the response will be treated as a valid HTTP header line such as "HTTP/1.0 200 OK". (Added in 7.10.3)
The alias itself is not parsed for any version strings. So if your alias is "MYHTTP/9.9", libcurl will not treat the server as responding with HTTP version 9.9. Instead libcurl will use the value set by option CURLOPT_HTTP_VERSION.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTPAUTH
member.summary: Pass an int as parameter, which is set to a bitmask of , to tell libcurl what authentication method(s) you want it to use. If more than one bit is set, libcurl will first query the site to see what authentication methods it supports and then pick the best one you allow it to use. Note that for some methods, this will induce an extra network round-trip. Set the actual name and password with the CURLOPT_USERPWD option. (Added in 7.10.6)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTPGET
member.summary: Pass a bool. If it's true, this forces the HTTP request to get back to GET. Usable if a POST, HEAD, PUT or a custom request has been used previously using the same object.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER
member.summary:
Pass an reference containing HTTP headers to pass to the server in your HTTP request. If you add a header that is otherwise generated and used by libcurl internally, your added one will be used instead. If you add a header with no contents as in 'Accept:' (no data on the right side of the colon), the internally used header will get disabled. Thus, using this option you can add new headers, replace internal headers and remove internal headers. The headers included in the Slist must not be CRLF-terminated, because curl adds CRLF after each header item. Failure to comply with this will result in strange bugs because the server will most likely ignore part of the headers you specified.
The first line in a request (usually containing a GET or POST) is not a header and cannot be replaced using this option. Only the lines following the request-line are headers.
Pass a null to this to reset back to no custom headers.
The most commonly replaced headers have "shortcuts" in the options CURLOPT_COOKIE, CURLOPT_USERAGENT and CURLOPT_REFERER.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTPPOST
member.summary:
Tells libcurl you want a multipart/formdata HTTP POST to be made and you instruct what data to pass on to the server. Pass a reference to a object as parameter. The best and most elegant way to do this, is to use as documented.
Using POST with HTTP 1.1 implies the use of a "Expect: 100-continue" header. You can disable this header with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER as usual.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTPPROXYTUNNEL
member.summary: Set the parameter to true to get the library to tunnel all operations through a given HTTP proxy. Note that there is a big difference between using a proxy and tunneling through it. If you don't know what this means, you probably don't want this tunneling option.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_HTTP_VERSION
member.summary: Pass a member of the enumeration. These values force libcurl to use the specific HTTP versions. This is not sensible to do unless you have a good reason.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_IOCTLFUNCTION
member.summary: Provide an delegate reference. This delegate gets called by libcurl when an IOCTL operation, such as a rewind of a file being sent via FTP, is required on the client side.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_IOCTLDATA
member.summary: Provide an object, such as a FileStream, upon which you may need to perform an IOCTL operation. Right now, only rewind is supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_INFILESIZE
member.summary: When uploading a file to a remote site, this option should be used to tell libcurl what the expected size of the infile is. This value should be passed as an int.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_INFILESIZE_LARGE
member.summary: When uploading a file to a remote site, this option should be used to tell libcurl what the expected size of the infile is. This value should be passed as a long. (Added in 7.11.0)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_INTERFACE
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. This sets the interface name to use as the outgoing network interface. The name can be an interface name, an IP address or a host name.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_IPRESOLVE
member.summary: Pass one of the members of the enumeration.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_KRB4LEVEL
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. Set the kerberos4 security level; this also enables kerberos4 awareness. This is a string, 'clear', 'safe', 'confidential' or 'private'. If the string is set but doesn't match one of these, 'private' will be used. Set the string to null to disable kerberos4. The kerberos support only works for FTP.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_LASTENTRY
member.summary: Last numeric entry in the enumeration. Don't use this in your application code.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_LOW_SPEED_LIMIT
member.summary: Pass an int as parameter. It contains the transfer speed in bytes per second that the transfer should be below during CURLOPT_LOW_SPEED_TIME seconds for the library to consider it too slow and abort.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_LOW_SPEED_TIME
member.summary: Pass an int as parameter. It contains the time in seconds that the transfer should be below the CURLOPT_LOW_SPEED_LIMIT for the library to consider it too slow and abort.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_MAXCONNECTS
member.summary:
Pass an int. The set number will be the persistent connection cache size. The set amount will be the maximum amount of simultaneously open connections that libcurl may cache. Default is 5, and there isn't much point in changing this value unless you are perfectly aware of how this works and changes libcurl's behaviour. This concerns connections using any of the protocols that support persistent connections.
When reaching the maximum limit, cURL uses the CURLOPT_CLOSEPOLICY to figure out which of the existing connections to close to prevent the number of open connections to increase.
if you already have performed transfers with this Easy object, setting a smaller CURLOPT_MAXCONNECTS than before may cause open connections to get closed unnecessarily.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_MAXFILESIZE
member.summary:
Pass an int as parameter. This allows you to specify the maximum size (in bytes) of a file to download. If the file requested is larger than this value, the transfer will not start and will be returned.
The file size is not always known prior to download, and for such files this option has no effect even if the file transfer ends up being larger than this given limit. This concerns both FTP and HTTP transfers.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_MAXFILESIZE_LARGE
member.summary:
Pass a long as parameter. This allows you to specify the maximum size (in bytes) of a file to download. If the file requested is larger than this value, the transfer will not start and will be returned. (Added in 7.11.0)
The file size is not always known prior to download, and for such files this option has no effect even if the file transfer ends up being larger than this given limit. This concerns both FTP and HTTP transfers.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_MAXREDIRS
member.summary: Pass an int. The set number will be the redirection limit. If that many redirections have been followed, the next redirect will cause an error (CURLE_TOO_MANY_REDIRECTS). This option only makes sense if the CURLOPT_FOLLOWLOCATION is used at the same time.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_NETRC
member.summary:
This parameter controls the preference of libcurl between using user names and passwords from your ~/.netrc file, relative to user names and passwords in the URL supplied with CURLOPT_URL.
libcurl uses a user name (and supplied or prompted password) supplied with CURLOPT_USERPWD in preference to any of the options controlled by this parameter.
Pass a member of the enumeration.
Only machine name, user name and password are taken into account (init macros and similar things aren't supported).
libcurl does not verify that the file has the correct properties set (as the standard Unix ftp client does). It should only be readable by user.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_NETRC_FILE
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter, containing the full path name to the file you want libcurl to use as .netrc file. If this option is omitted, and CURLOPT_NETRC is set, libcurl will attempt to find the a .netrc file in the current user's home directory. (Added in 7.10.9)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_NOBODY
member.summary:
A true parameter tells the library to not include the body-part in the output. This is only relevant for protocols that have separate header and body parts. On HTTP(S) servers, this will make libcurl do a HEAD request.
To change back to GET, you should use CURLOPT_HTTPGET. To change back to POST, you should use CURLOPT_POST. Setting CURLOPT_NOBODY to false has no effect.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_NOPROGRESS
member.summary: A true parameter tells the library to shut off progress reporting.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_NOSIGNAL
member.summary:
Pass a bool. If it is true, libcurl will not use any functions that install signal handlers or any functions that cause signals to be sent to the process. This option is mainly here to allow multi-threaded unix applications to still set/use all timeout options etc, without risking getting signals. (Added in 7.10)
Consider using libcurl with ares built-in to enable asynchronous DNS lookups. It enables nice timeouts for name resolves without signals.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PASV_HOST
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PORT
member.summary: Pass an int specifying what remote port number to connect to, instead of the one specified in the URL or the default port for the used protocol.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_POST
member.summary:
A true parameter tells the library to do a regular HTTP post. This will also make the library use the a "Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded" header. (This is by far the most commonly used POST method).
Use the CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS option to specify what data to post and CURLOPT_POSTFIELDSIZE to set the data size. Optionally, you can provide data to POST using the CURLOPT_READFUNCTION and CURLOPT_READDATA options.
You can override the default POST Content-Type: header by setting your own with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER.
Using POST with HTTP 1.1 implies the use of a "Expect: 100-continue" header. You can disable this header with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER as usual.
If you use POST to a HTTP 1.1 server, you can send data without knowing the size before starting the POST if you use chunked encoding. You enable this by adding a header like "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER. With HTTP 1.0 or without chunked transfer, you must specify the size in the request.
if you have issued a POST request and want to make a HEAD or GET instead, you must explictly pick the new request type using CURLOPT_NOBODY or CURLOPT_HTTPGET or similar.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter, which should be the full data to post in an HTTP POST operation. You must make sure that the data is formatted the way you want the server to receive it. libcurl will not convert or encode it for you. Most web servers will assume this data to be url-encoded. Take note.
This POST is a normal application/x-www-form-urlencoded kind (and libcurl will set that Content-Type by default when this option is used), which is the most commonly used one by HTML forms. See also the CURLOPT_POST. Using CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS implies CURLOPT_POST.
Using POST with HTTP 1.1 implies the use of a "Expect: 100-continue" header. You can disable this header with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER as usual.
to make multipart/formdata posts (aka rfc1867-posts), check out the CURLOPT_HTTPPOST option.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_POSTFIELDSIZE
member.summary: If you want to post data to the server without letting libcurl do a strlen() to measure the data size, this option must be used. When this option is used you can post fully binary data, which otherwise is likely to fail. If this size is set to zero, the library will use strlen() to get the size.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_POSTFIELDSIZE_LARGE
member.summary: Pass a long as parameter. Use this to set the size of the CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS data to prevent libcurl from doing strlen() on the data to figure out the size. This is the large file version of the CURLOPT_POSTFIELDSIZE option. (Added in 7.11.1)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_POSTQUOTE
member.summary: Pass an of FTP commands to pass to the server after your ftp transfer request. Disable this operation again by setting this option to null.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PREQUOTE
member.summary: Pass an containing the FTP commands to pass to the server after the transfer type is set. Disable this operation again by setting a null to this option.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PRIVATE
member.summary: Pass an object as parameter, referencing data that should be associated with this object. The object can subsequently be retrieved using with the option. libcurl itself does nothing with this data. (Added in 7.10.3)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROGRESSDATA
member.summary: Pass an object reference that will be untouched by libcurl and passed as the first argument in the progress delegate set with CURLOPT_PROGRESSFUNCTION.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROGRESSFUNCTION
member.summary:
Pass an delegate reference. This delegate gets called by libcurl at a frequent interval during data transfer. Unknown/unused argument values will be set to zero (like if you only download data, the upload size will remain 0). Returning a non-zero value from this delegate will cause libcurl to abort the transfer and return .
CURLOPT_NOPROGRESS must be set to false to make this function actually get called.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROXY
member.summary:
Set HTTP proxy to use. The parameter should be a string holding the host name or dotted IP address. To specify port number in this string, append :[port] to the end of the host name. The proxy string may be prefixed with [protocol]:// since any such prefix will be ignored. The proxy's port number may optionally be specified with the separate option CURLOPT_PROXYPORT.
NOTE: when you tell the library to use an HTTP proxy, libcurl will transparently convert operations to HTTP even if you specify an FTP URL etc. This may have an impact on what other features of the library you can use, such as CURLOPT_QUOTE and similar FTP specifics that don't work unless you tunnel through the HTTP proxy. Such tunneling is activated with CURLOPT_HTTPPROXYTUNNEL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROXYAUTH
member.summary: Pass a bitmask of as the paramter, to tell libcurl what authentication method(s) you want it to use for your proxy authentication. If more than one bit is set, libcurl will first query the site to see what authentication methods it supports and then pick the best one you allow it to use. Note that for some methods, this will induce an extra network round-trip. Set the actual name and password with the CURLOPT_PROXYUSERPWD option. The bitmask can be constructed by or'ing together the bits. As of this writing, only and work. (Added in 7.10.7)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROXYPORT
member.summary: Pass an int with this option to set the proxy port to connect to unless it is specified in the proxy string CURLOPT_PROXY.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROXYTYPE
member.summary: Pass a to set type of the proxy.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PROXYUSERPWD
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter, which should be [user name]:[password] to use for the connection to the HTTP proxy. Use CURLOPT_PROXYAUTH to decide authentication method.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_PUT
member.summary:
A true parameter tells the library to use HTTP PUT to transfer data. The data should be set with CURLOPT_READDATA and CURLOPT_INFILESIZE.
This option is deprecated and starting with version 7.12.1 you should instead use CURLOPT_UPLOAD.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_QUOTE
member.summary: Pass a reference to an containing FTP commands to pass to the server prior to your ftp request. This will be done before any other FTP commands are issued (even before the CWD command). Disable this operation again by setting a null to this option.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_RANDOM_FILE
member.summary: Pass a string containing the file name. The file will be used to read from to seed the random engine for SSL. The more random the specified file is, the more secure the SSL connection will become.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_RANGE
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter, which should contain the specified range you want. It should be in the format X-Y, where X or Y may be left out. HTTP transfers also support several intervals, separated with commas as in X-Y,N-M. Using this kind of multiple intervals will cause the HTTP server to send the response document in pieces (using standard MIME separation techniques). Pass a null to this option to disable the use of ranges.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_READDATA
member.summary: Object reference to pass to the delegate. Note that if you specify the CURLOPT_READFUNCTION, this is the reference you'll get as input.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_READFUNCTION
member.summary:
Pass a reference to an delegate. This delegate gets called by libcurl as soon as it needs to read data in order to send it to the peer. The data area referenced by the buf may be filled with at most size multiplied with nmemb number of bytes. Your function must return the actual number of bytes that you stored in that byte array. Returning 0 will signal end-of-file to the library and cause it to stop the current transfer.
If you stop the current transfer by returning 0 "pre-maturely" (i.e before the server expected it, like when you've told you will upload N bytes and you upload less than N bytes), you may experience that the server "hangs" waiting for the rest of the data that won't come.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_REFERER
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. It will be used to set the Referer: header in the http request sent to the remote server. This can be used to fool servers or scripts. You can also set any custom header with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_RESUME_FROM
member.summary: Pass an int as parameter. It contains the offset in number of bytes that you want the transfer to start from. Set this option to 0 to make the transfer start from the beginning (effectively disabling resume).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_RESUME_FROM_LARGE
member.summary: Pass a long as parameter. It contains the offset in number of bytes that you want the transfer to start from. (Added in 7.11.0)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SHARE
member.summary: Pass an initialized reference as a parameter. Setting this option will make this object use the data from the Share object instead of keeping the data to itself. This enables several Easy objects to share data. If the Easy objects are used simultaneously, you MUST use the Share object's locking methods. See for details.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_HOST
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_PATH
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_PORT
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_POSTQUOTE
member.summary: When doing a third-party transfer, set the source post-quote list, as an .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_PREQUOTE
member.summary: When doing a third-party transfer, set the source pre-quote list, as an .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_QUOTE
member.summary: When doing a third-party transfer, set a quote list, as an .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_URL
member.summary: Set the source URL for a third-party transfer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SOURCE_USERPWD
member.summary: When doing 3rd party transfer, set the source user and password, as a string with format user:password.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLCERT
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. The string should be the file name of your certificate. The default format is "PEM" and can be changed with CURLOPT_SSLCERTTYPE.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLCERTPASSWD
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. It will be used as the password required to use the CURLOPT_SSLCERT certificate.
This option is replaced by CURLOPT_SSLKEYPASSWD and should only be used for backward compatibility. You never needed a pass phrase to load a certificate but you need one to load your private key.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLCERTTYPE
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. The string should be the format of your certificate. Supported formats are "PEM" and "DER". (Added in 7.9.3)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLENGINE
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. It will be used as the identifier for the crypto engine you want to use for your private key.
If the crypto device cannot be loaded, is returned.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLENGINE_DEFAULT
member.summary:
Sets the actual crypto engine as the default for (asymmetric) crypto operations.
If the crypto device cannot be set, is returned.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLKEY
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. The string should be the file name of your private key. The default format is "PEM" and can be changed with CURLOPT_SSLKEYTYPE.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLKEYPASSWD
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. It will be used as the password required to use the CURLOPT_SSLKEY private key.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLKEYTYPE
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter. The string should be the format of your private key. Supported formats are "PEM", "DER" and "ENG".
The format "ENG" enables you to load the private key from a crypto engine. In this case CURLOPT_SSLKEY is used as an identifier passed to the engine. You have to set the crypto engine with CURLOPT_SSLENGINE. "DER" format key file currently does not work because of a bug in OpenSSL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSLVERSION
member.summary: Pass a member of the enumeration as the parameter to set the SSL version to use. By default the SSL library will try to solve this by itself although some servers servers make this difficult why you at times may have to use this option.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSL_CIPHER_LIST
member.summary:
Pass a string holding the list of ciphers to use for the SSL connection. The list must be syntactically correct, it consists of one or more cipher strings separated by colons. Commas or spaces are also acceptable separators but colons are normally used, !, - and + can be used as operators. Valid examples of cipher lists include 'RC4-SHA', SHA1+DES, 'TLSv1' and 'DEFAULT'. The default list is normally set when you compile OpenSSL.
You'll find more details about cipher lists on this URL: http://www.openssl.org/docs/apps/ciphers.html

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSL_CTX_DATA
member.summary: Object reference to pass to the ssl context delegate set by the option CURLOPT_SSL_CTX_FUNCTION, this is the pointer you'll get as the second parameter, otherwise null. (Added in 7.11.0)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSL_CTX_FUNCTION
member.summary:
Reference to an delegate. This delegate gets called by libcurl just before the initialization of an SSL connection after having processed all other SSL related options to give a last chance to an application to modify the behaviour of openssl's ssl initialization. The parameter wraps a pointer to an openssl SSL_CTX. If an error is returned no attempt to establish a connection is made and the perform operation will return the error code from this callback function. Set the parm argument with the CURLOPT_SSL_CTX_DATA option. This option was introduced in 7.11.0.
To use this properly, a non-trivial amount of knowledge of the openssl libraries is necessary. Using this function allows for example to use openssl callbacks to add additional validation code for certificates, and even to change the actual URI of an HTTPS request.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYHOST
member.summary: Pass an int. Set if we should verify the common name from the peer certificate in the SSL handshake, set 1 to check existence, 2 to ensure that it matches the provided hostname. This is by default set to 2. (default changed in 7.10)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER
member.summary: Pass a bool that is set to false to stop curl from verifying the peer's certificate (7.10 starting setting this option to non-zero by default). Alternate certificates to verify against can be specified with the CURLOPT_CAINFO option or a certificate directory can be specified with the CURLOPT_CAPATH option. As of 7.10, curl installs a default bundle. CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYHOST may also need to be set to 1 or 0 if CURLOPT_SSL_VERIFYPEER is disabled (it defaults to 2).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_STDERR
member.summary: Not supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_TCP_NODELAY
member.summary:
Pass a bool specifying whether the TCP_NODELAY option should be set or cleared (true = set, false = clear). The option is cleared by default. This will have no effect after the connection has been established.
Setting this option will disable TCP's Nagle algorithm. The purpose of this algorithm is to try to minimize the number of small packets on the network (where "small packets" means TCP segments less than the Maximum Segment Size (MSS) for the network).
Maximizing the amount of data sent per TCP segment is good because it amortizes the overhead of the send. However, in some cases (most notably telnet or rlogin) small segments may need to be sent without delay. This is less efficient than sending larger amounts of data at a time, and can contribute to congestion on the network if overdone.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS
member.summary: Provide an with variables to pass to the telnet negotiations. The variables should be in the format "option=value". libcurl supports the options 'TTYPE', 'XDISPLOC' and 'NEW_ENV'. See the TELNET standard for details.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_TIMECONDITION
member.summary:
Pass a member of the enumeration as parameter. This defines how the CURLOPT_TIMEVALUE time value is treated. This feature applies to HTTP and FTP.
The last modification time of a file is not always known and in such instances this feature will have no effect even if the given time condition would have not been met.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_TIMEOUT
member.summary:
Pass a int as parameter containing the maximum time in seconds that you allow the libcurl transfer operation to take. Normally, name lookups can take a considerable time and limiting operations to less than a few minutes risk aborting perfectly normal operations. This option will cause curl to use the SIGALRM to enable time-outing system calls.
this is not recommended to use in unix multi-threaded programs, as it uses signals unless CURLOPT_NOSIGNAL (see above) is set.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_TIMEVALUE
member.summary: Pass a as parameter. This time will be used in a condition as specified with CURLOPT_TIMECONDITION.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_TRANSFERTEXT
member.summary: A true parameter tells the library to use ASCII mode for ftp transfers, instead of the default binary transfer. For LDAP transfers it gets the data in plain text instead of HTML and for win32 systems it does not set the stdout to binary mode. This option can be usable when transferring text data between systems with different views on certain characters, such as newlines or similar.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_UNRESTRICTED_AUTH
member.summary: A true parameter tells the library it can continue to send authentication (user+password) when following locations, even when hostname changed. Note that this is meaningful only when setting CURLOPT_FOLLOWLOCATION.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_UPLOAD
member.summary:
A true parameter tells the library to prepare for an upload. The CURLOPT_READDATA and CURLOPT_INFILESIZE or CURLOPT_INFILESIZE_LARGE are also interesting for uploads. If the protocol is HTTP, uploading means using the PUT request unless you tell libcurl otherwise.
Using PUT with HTTP 1.1 implies the use of a "Expect: 100-continue" header. You can disable this header with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER as usual.
If you use PUT to a HTTP 1.1 server, you can upload data without knowing the size before starting the transfer if you use chunked encoding. You enable this by adding a header like "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER. With HTTP 1.0 or without chunked transfer, you must specify the size.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_URL
member.summary:
The actual URL to deal with. The parameter should be a string. If the given URL lacks the protocol part ("http://" or "ftp://" etc), it will attempt to guess which protocol to use based on the given host name.
If the given protocol of the set URL is not supported, libcurl will return an error CURLcode.() when you call Easy's or Multi's .
Use for detailed info on which protocols that are supported.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_USERAGENT
member.summary: Pass a string as parameter. It will be used to set the User-Agent: header in the http request sent to the remote server. This can be used to fool servers or scripts. You can also set any custom header with CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_USERPWD
member.summary:
Pass a string as parameter, which should be [user name]:[password] to use for the connection. Use CURLOPT_HTTPAUTH to decide authentication method.
When using HTTP and CURLOPT_FOLLOWLOCATION, libcurl might perform several requests to possibly different hosts. libcurl will only send this user and password information to hosts using the initial host name (unless CURLOPT_UNRESTRICTED_AUTH is set), so if libcurl follows locations to other hosts it will not send the user and password to those. This is enforced to prevent accidental information leakage.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_VERBOSE
member.summary: Set the parameter to true to get the library to display a lot of verbose information about its operations. Very useful for libcurl and/or protocol debugging and understanding. The verbose information will be sent to the delegate, if it's implemented. You hardly ever want this set in production use, you will almost always want this when you debug/report problems.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_WRITEDATA
member.summary: Object reference to pass to the delegate. Note that if you specify the CURLOPT_WRITEFUNCTION, this is the object you'll get as input.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_WRITEFUNCTION
member.summary: Pass a reference to an delegate. The delegate gets called by libcurl as soon as there is data received that needs to be saved. The size of the data referenced by buf is size multiplied with nmemb, it will not be zero terminated. Return the number of bytes actually taken care of. If that amount differs from the amount passed to your function, it'll signal an error to the library and it will abort the transfer and return CURLcode.. This function may be called with zero bytes data if the transfered file is empty.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLoption.CURLOPT_WRITEINFO
member.summary: Pass a string of the output using full variable-replacement as described elsewhere.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLipResolve
member.summary: This enumeration contains values used to specify the IP resolution method when using the option in a call to

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLipResolve.CURL_IPRESOLVE_WHATEVER
member.summary: Default, resolves addresses to all IP versions that your system allows.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLipResolve.CURL_IPRESOLVE_V4
member.summary: Resolve to ipv4 addresses.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLipResolve.CURL_IPRESOLVE_V6
member.summary: Resolve to ipv6 addresses.

member.summary: Contains values used to specify the HTTP version level when using the option in a call to

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpVersion.CURL_HTTP_VERSION_NONE
member.summary: We don't care about what version the library uses. libcurl will use whatever it thinks fit.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLhttpVersion.CURL_HTTP_VERSION_1_0
member.summary: Enforce HTTP 1.0 requests.

member.summary: Contains values used to specify the preference of libcurl between using user names and passwords from your ~/.netrc file, relative to user names and passwords in the URL supplied with . This is passed when using the option in a call to

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLnetrcOption.CURL_NETRC_IGNORED
member.summary: The library will ignore the file and use only the information in the URL. This is the default.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLnetrcOption.CURL_NETRC_OPTIONAL
member.summary:
The use of your ~/.netrc file is optional, and information in the URL is to be preferred. The file will be scanned with the host and user name (to find the password only) or with the host only, to find the first user name and password after that machine, which ever information is not specified in the URL.
Undefined values of the option will have this effect.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLnetrcOption.CURL_NETRC_REQUIRED
member.summary: This value tells the library that use of the file is required, to ignore the information in the URL, and to search the file with the host only.

member.summary: The time condition is true if the resource has been modified since the date/time passed in .

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption
member.summary: These are options available to build a multi-part form section in a call to

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_ARRAY
member.summary: Another possibility to send options to is this option, that passes a array reference as its value. Each array element has a and a string. All available options can be used in an array, except the CURLFORM_ARRAY option itself! The last argument in such an array must always be CURLFORM_END.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_BUFFER
member.summary: Followed by a string, tells libcurl that a buffer is to be used to upload data instead of using a file.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_BUFFERLENGTH
member.summary: Followed by an int with the size of the CURLFORM_BUFFERPTR byte array, tells libcurl the length of the data to upload.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_BUFFERPTR
member.summary: Followed by a byte[] array, tells libcurl the address of the buffer containing data to upload (as indicated with CURLFORM_BUFFER). You must also use CURLFORM_BUFFERLENGTH to set the length of the buffer area.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_CONTENTHEADER
member.summary: Specifies extra headers for the form POST section. This takes an prepared in the usual way using and appends the list of headers to those libcurl automatically generates.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_CONTENTSLENGTH
member.summary: Followed by an int setting the length of the contents.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_CONTENTTYPE
member.summary: Followed by a string with a content-type will make cURL use this given content-type for this file upload part, possibly instead of an internally chosen one.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_COPYCONTENTS
member.summary: Followed by a string is used for the contents of this part, the actual data to send away. If you'd like it to contain zero bytes, you need to set the length of the name with CURLFORM_CONTENTSLENGTH.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_COPYNAME
member.summary: Followed by a string used to set the name of this part. If you'd like it to contain zero bytes, you need to set the length of the name with CURLFORM_NAMELENGTH.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_END
member.summary: This should be the last argument to a call to .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_FILE
member.summary: Followed by a file name, makes this part a file upload part. It sets the file name field to the actual file name used here, it gets the contents of the file and passes as data and sets the content-type if the given file match one of the new internally known file extension. For CURLFORM_FILE the user may send one or more files in one part by providing multiple CURLFORM_FILE arguments each followed by the filename (and each CURLFORM_FILE is allowed to have a CURLFORM_CONTENTTYPE).

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_FILECONTENT

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLformoption.CURLFORM_FILENAME
member.summary: Followed by a string file name, will make libcurl use the given name in the file upload part, instead of the actual file name given to CURLFORM_FILE.
