member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO
member.summary: This enumeration is used to extract information associated with an transfer. Specifically, a member of this enumeration is passed as the first argument to specifying the item to retrieve in the second argument, which is a reference to an int, a double, a string, a DateTime or an object.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_CONNECT_TIME
member.summary: The second argument receives the elapsed time, as a double, in seconds, from the start until the connect to the remote host (or proxy) was completed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_CONTENT_LENGTH_DOWNLOAD
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a double, the content-length of the download. This is the value read from the Content-Length: field.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_CONTENT_LENGTH_UPLOAD
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a double, the specified size of the upload.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_CONTENT_TYPE
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a string, the content-type of the downloaded object. This is the value read from the Content-Type: field. If you get null, it means that the server didn't send a valid Content-Type header or that the protocol used doesn't support this.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_EFFECTIVE_URL
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a string, the last used effective URL.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_FILETIME
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a long, the remote time of the retrieved document. You should construct a DateTime from this value, as shown in the InfoDemo sample. If you get a date in the distant past, it can be because of many reasons (unknown, the server hides it or the server doesn't support the command that tells document time etc) and the time of the document is unknown. Note that you must tell the server to collect this information before the transfer is made, by using the option to . (Added in 7.5)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_HEADER_SIZE
member.summary: The second argument receives an int specifying the total size of all the headers received.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_HTTPAUTH_AVAIL
member.summary: The second argument receives, as an int, a bitmask indicating the authentication method(s) available. The meaning of the bits is explained in the documentation of . (Added in 7.10.8)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_HTTP_CONNECTCODE
member.summary: The second argument receives an int indicating the numeric connect code for the HTTP request.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_LASTONE
member.summary: End-of-enumeration marker; do not use in client applications.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_NAMELOOKUP_TIME
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a double, the time, in seconds it took from the start until the name resolving was completed.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_NONE
member.summary: Never used.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_NUM_CONNECTS
member.summary: The second argument receives an int indicating the number of current connections. (Added in 7.13.0)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_OS_ERRNO
member.summary: The second argument receives an int indicating the operating system error number: _errro or GetLastError(), depending on the platform. (Added in 7.12.2)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_PRETRANSFER_TIME
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a double, the time, in seconds, it took from the start until the file transfer is just about to begin. This includes all pre-transfer commands and negotiations that are specific to the particular protocol(s) involved.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_PRIVATE
member.summary: The second argument receives a reference to the private data associated with the object (set with the option to . (Added in 7.10.3)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_PROXYAUTH_AVAIL
member.summary: The second argument receives, as an int, a bitmask indicating the authentication method(s) available for your proxy authentication. This will be a bitmask of enumeration constants. (Added in 7.10.8)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_REDIRECT_COUNT
member.summary: The second argument receives an int indicating the total number of redirections that were actually followed. (Added in 7.9.7)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_REDIRECT_TIME
member.summary: The second argument receives, as a double, the total time, in seconds, for all redirection steps include name lookup, connect, pretransfer and transfer before final transaction was started. CURLINFO_REDIRECT_TIME contains the complete execution time for multiple redirections. (Added in 7.9.7)

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_REQUEST_SIZE
member.summary: The second argument receives an int containing the total size of the issued requests. This is so far only for HTTP requests. Note that this may be more than one request if is true.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_RESPONSE_CODE
member.summary: The second argument receives an int with the last received HTTP or FTP code. This option was known as CURLINFO_HTTP_CODE in libcurl 7.10.7 and earlier.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_SIZE_DOWNLOAD
member.summary: The second argument receives a double with the total amount of bytes that were downloaded. The amount is only for the latest transfer and will be reset again for each new transfer.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_SIZE_UPLOAD
member.summary: The second argument receives a double with the total amount of bytes that were uploaded.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_SPEED_DOWNLOAD
member.summary: The second argument receives a double with the average download speed that cURL measured for the complete download.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_SPEED_UPLOAD
member.summary: The second argument receives a double with the average upload speed that libcurl measured for the complete upload.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_SSL_ENGINES
member.summary: The second argument receives an containing the names of the available SSL engines.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_SSL_VERIFYRESULT
member.summary: The second argument receives an int with the result of the certificate verification that was requested (using the option in .

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_STARTTRANSFER_TIME
member.summary: The second argument receives a double specifying the time, in seconds, from the start until the first byte is just about to be transferred. This includes CURLINFO_PRETRANSFER_TIME and also the time the server needs to calculate the result.

member.name: F:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.CURLINFO.CURLINFO_TOTAL_TIME
member.summary: The second argument receives a double indicating the total transaction time in seconds for the previous transfer. This time does not include the connect time, so if you want the complete operation time, you should add the CURLINFO_CONNECT_TIME.

member.name: M:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.MultiPartForm.AddSection(System.Object[])
member.summary: Add a multi-part form section.
member.param: Argument list, as described in the remarks.
member.remarks:
This is definitely the workhorse method for this class. It should be called in roughly the same manner as curl_formadd(), except you would omit the first two struct curl_httppost** arguments (firstitem and lastitem), which are wrapped in this class. So you should pass arguments in the following sequence:
MultiPartForm.AddSection(option1, value1, ..., optionX, valueX, CURLformoption.CURLFORM_END);
For a complete list of possible options, see the documentation for the enumeration.
The pointer options (CURLFORM_PTRNAME, etc.) make an internal copy of the passed byte array. Therefore, any changes you make to the client copy of this array AFTER calling this method, won't be reflected internally with cURL. The purpose of providing the pointer options is to support the posting of non-string binary data.

member.name: T:SeasideResearch.LibCurlNet.Share.LockFunction
member.summary: Called when cURL wants to lock a shared resource.
member.remarks:
For a usage example, refer to the ShareDemo.cs sample. Arguments passed to your delegate implementation include:
Argument Description
data
Type of data to lock; one of the values in the enumeration.
access
